args: Oh, it's you, {player_name}.\nIt's a fine place, your castle.

I've been thinking it for some time.
While this castle may find itself at the
center of the occasional crisis, it always
has a strange sense of peace about it.
I wonder if that is because of you.
I think it's just because the people in it\nwant to live in peace, personally.
It's almost too peaceful for someone like\nme. I can see my skills growing rusty.
So while I have nothing to do,\nI think I will go hunting.
Sorry, but I think I'll pass.
I'm not opposed to hunting for sustenance,\nbut I don't want to hurt another living\ncreature just because I'm bored.
Talking to you really makes me realize\nhow tainted I truly am.
Oh. Sorry. I wasn't trying to deny your way\nof life or anything.
No. What you are saying is quite correct.
But what would you say to coming on a\nhunt where no one will be hurt?
Er, how would that even work?
If you're curious, why not come?
All I see is a bunch of dead leaves.
On the surface. But if we move them...
Oh, I see tracks! Are these...bear tracks?
I'm impressed you could tell.\nBut this is no ordinary bear.
You'll find out soon enough.\nCome. Let's follow them.
No. This creature walked backward over\nits own tracks, then went in a different\ndirection.

It's called backtracking. It's a technique
commonly employed by animals that
want to evade their pursuers, though it's
quite rare in carnivores.
It is necessary knowledge for a hunter.\nNow let us resume our pursuit.
Something has been burying berries here.\nWe're in its territory.
We must be even more cautious from here\non out. Be very quiet.
This way. Follow me—and stay low.
Correct. Look over there—but don't move\nfrom the shadow of the trees.
And a slightly peculiar one, too.\nLook down, near its feet.
But that bear's a carnivore, right?\nSo won't it...?
Don't worry. Watch, and you will see that\nyour fears are unfounded.
Interesting, yes? This is a species called\na rearing bear.
For some reason, it raises the young of\nother species.
Well, we should make our way back.\nWe don't want it to notice us.
I don't want to tear my eyes away,\nbut you're probably right.
...Hold on. What happened to the hunting?
When a rearing bear is with another\nanimal, it becomes deeply cautious,\nnever showing itself in front of people.
What we just saw is a rare sight indeed.
Okay, that makes sense. But what does it\nhave to do with hunting?
That heartwarming sight WAS the hunt.
And I understand what you meant when\nyou said no one would be hurt.
Most of a hunter's work is approaching\nprey without being noticed and securing\na position to deal the fatal blow.
By the time you've nocked your arrow,\nyour target's fate should already be sealed.
Which is why this is a valid method to\nhone your hunting instincts.
That was a really fun hunt, Hawk.\nI'd be more than happy to come\nwith you on another one sometime.
